todaysEvents.title: Ledger-Trezor Phishing Scam Following Global-e Breach
todaysEvents.description: Ledger users are being targeted by a phishing campaign featuring a fake merger between Ledger and Trezor. This follows a data breach at Ledger's e-commerce partner, Global-e, which exposed customer contact and order information.

todaysEvents.title: Flow Counterfeit Token Exploit
todaysEvents.description: Flow released details regarding a December exploit involving counterfeit tokens that resulted in losses totaling $3.9 million.

todaysEvents.title: NordVPN Alleged Data Leak Denial
todaysEvents.description: NordVPN has officially denied claims of a data breach following reports that a hacker leaked company data online.

todaysEvents.title: Multi-Signature Wallet $27.3M PeckShield ETH Laundering
todaysEvents.description: A hacker successfully exploited a multi-signature wallet to steal approximately $27.3 million, with subsequent reports from PeckShield indicating the attacker is laundering the stolen ETH.

todaysEvents.title: ClickFix BSOD Malware Attack Campaign
todaysEvents.description: The ClickFix attack campaign is reportedly utilizing deceptive Windows Blue Screen of Death (BSOD) screens to trick users into installing malware.

past7Days.briefing: During the first week of 2026, the cyber threat landscape was marked by a series of high-severity incidents, predominantly targeting the cryptocurrency sector, e-commerce platforms, and personal data repositories. Major financial losses resulted from sophisticated exploits and phishing campaigns, including multi-million dollar thefts from Unleash Protocol, Flow, and multi-signature wallet attacks, as well as widespread wallet-draining scams leveraging phishing tactics against MetaMask and Ledger users. E-commerce and retail sectors faced significant breaches, such as the compromise of Italian site OfferteCartucce and Mexico's Farmacia San Pablo, exposing sensitive user and operational data. The prevalence of advanced malware campaigns (e.g., Android banking malware, ClickFix BSOD scams) and exploitation of critical vulnerabilities (Next.js servers, Trust Wallet extension) underscores the evolving and multi-vector nature of current cyber risks. Notably, persistent threats from previous breaches (LastPass, Global-e) continue to facilitate new attacks, highlighting the importance of ongoing vigilance and robust incident response.
past7Days.trends: The data reveals several clear trends: 1) Cryptocurrency platforms and wallets remain prime targets, with a noticeable spike in high-value exploits, wallet-draining attacks, and scam campaigns—phishing and social engineering are increasingly sophisticated, using themed lures and realistic 2FA flows. 2) Data breaches involving large-scale personal information leaks are frequent, affecting both educational institutions and retail/e-commerce sectors. 3) Malware and botnet activity is on the rise, with attacks exploiting new vulnerabilities (Next.js, React2Shell) and targeting both servers and end-users (Android malware, BSOD scam). 4) Attackers are rapidly adapting tactics, leveraging historical breaches and exploiting supply chain partners to expand victim reach. Overall, threat scores remained consistently high, peaking mid-week, with no significant decline in intensity.
past7Days.predictions: For the upcoming days, expect continued high risk in the cryptocurrency and financial services space, with further exploitation of wallet, exchange, and aggregator vulnerabilities. Advanced phishing and social engineering campaigns are likely to proliferate, leveraging emerging events and historical data leaks with increasing realism. The attack surface for e-commerce, healthcare, and educational sectors will remain vulnerable to data compromise, especially as attackers seek new entry points via supply chain partners and misconfigured cloud environments. Watch for more botnet-driven exploits targeting popular frameworks and browser extensions. Confidence in these predictions is high (80–90%) given the sustained volume and sophistication of recent attacks. Organizations should prioritize securing endpoints, educating users on phishing, and monitoring for anomalous activity linked to both new and historical breaches.
